Algorithms Illuminated Pt 1, Ch 6 Exercises

25 Jun 2018
  • algorithmsilluminated
  • roughgarden
  • bookexercises
  • java
« Last Post Next Post »


Note: those marked with an asterisk I am not 100% confident in my answer/reasoning.

Please feel free to discuss the problems and my proposed solutions below!

6.1

In order for the first recursive call to be passed a subarray of length at most αn, where α is strictly between 0.5 and 1, the pivot must be located between two indices at αn and n - αn from one endpoint of the array. The size of this region is αn - (n - αn) = n(2α - 1). Thus 2α - 1 is the fraction of the array that the pivot can be in and is therefore the probability of the conditions being satisfied.

D is the correct answer.

6.2

This will require the same reasoning used in problem 5.3. The maximum number of successive recursive calls occurs in the worst case scenario, which is when the subarray is αn. Hence, the answer will be .

Choice A is equivalent to this.

6.3

A linear deterministic algorithm for finding a “weighted median” of an array of n distinct elements each with a corresponding weight, w, could be the following implementation:

Java

It first finds the middle ith statistic in the array via dselect. Upon returning the ith statistic in the array, dselect will partition the array around the ith statistic as a side effect. The algorithm can then compute the left and right sums, and whichever half has a larger sum must contain the weighted median. So then it will recurse on that half. This repeats until the weighted median is found. At each recursion level one recursive call is made and each time it is called on an array that is half the size of the previous array. This, along with the fact that every operation is linear, implies the algorithm is indeed deterministic and linear.

However, there is a possibility for there to be at most 2 weighted medians. But this is easy to account for as the weighted medians will be neighboring statistics. So just check if i-1th and i+1th statistics are weighted medians as well after running the above algorithm. Since this is always a constant 2 extra calculations, this does not change the linearity of the algorithm.

6.4

If one were to modify the DSelect algorithm to use groups of 7 instead of 5, it will still run in O(n). The proof is the same as in the text, only the recurrence relation will be:

The strategy used in the text was to come up with a value for c so that this relation simplifies to . One can use c = 11*l/70 so it’s clear that using groups of 7 will still be O(n).

Groups of 3, however, the algorithm, in its current design, will no longer be linear. Trying to do the same as above for groups of 7, it is determined that c = -l/30. But both c and l must be positive values so it is impossible to be O(n).

However, recent literature proposes ways to make it O(n). See here.

Programming Challenge

We’re asked to implement rselect. Both rselect and dselect are implemented below:
